title: Variceal Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding
diagnosis_topic: Esophageal or gastric variceal hemorrhage secondary to portal hypertension
setup_script: A 54-year-old man with known alcoholic cirrhosis presents with large volume hematemesis and melena. He is hypotensive and confused.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 85/50 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 36.8 C.
Patient is altered with poor gag reflex; intubate for airway protection and resuscitation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates fluid resuscitation and transfusion
dynamic_flow.reply: Two large-bore IVs placed; transfuse packed RBCs aiming for Hgb 7-8 g/dL.
Octreotide infusion started to reduce portal pressure.
Ceftriaxone 1 g IV to prevent infection and rebleeding.
Large clots aspirated; confirms upper GI source.
Gastroenterologist performs endoscopic variceal band ligation of bleeding varices.
Balloon tamponade or TIPS (transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt) considered as rescue therapy.
Patient may exsanguinate or develop aspiration pneumonia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for hepatic encephalopathy
dynamic_flow.reply: Start lactulose if mental status deteriorates after bleeding controlled.
Non-selective beta blockers and repeat banding sessions to prevent rebleeding.
Abstinence from alcohol and referral to transplant center for evaluation.

critical_decision_points: Airway protection and resuscitation in variceal hemorrhage
Use of vasoactive agents and prophylactic antibiotics
Prompt endoscopic intervention with banding or sclerotherapy
Rescue therapy with balloon tamponade or TIPS when endoscopy fails
Post-bleed management including secondary prophylaxis and transplant evaluation
